reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Doors
Original Release: 2016
Genre Tags: Casual; Brain-Game; Puzzle; Short
My Overall Grade: B-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 1-2 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Puzzle gamers; Casual gamers
I received an activation key of this game from a press kit for the purposes of writing a review.  This did not affect my opinion; I will only recommend games that I like. If I do not like a game, I will not recommend it. Period. View my mission statement.
REVIEWDoors is a very simple game that puts a modern-indie-game spin on the classic logic puzzle of The Honest and Dishonest Guards. There isn’t much innovation to the gameplay, but there is a good atmospheric presentation and an alluring simplicity to it all. I enjoyed it, but I can confidently say that not everyone will. I really enjoy solving the style of logic puzzles used in the game; I even sometimes look up riddles similar to these for entertainment when I’m bored at work. If you like this kind of thinking game too, then you should consider trying this game; but also be aware it is very short, and will be beaten in one sitting.

So, yes, Doors is very short. If you approach the game with a comfortable pace, and actually solve the riddles, it will probably last about the same amount of time as a modern Hollywood movie. I like short games a lot, because I like variety and won’t live forever, but I will say that I would have been more content with more content. Yes. Mostly because I was enjoying it and I wasn’t ready for it to be over. It definitely could benefit from another hour or so of gameplay.

The riddles start off pretty easy, and slowly get more complicated as you go on. Some of them towards the end are quite tricky and the final puzzle is definitely hardcore. If you get stuck you may be tempted to just bulldoze the puzzles with good ol’ trial and error, but you would only be eliminating the purpose of the game (which is to solve the riddles by understanding them).

The atmosphere is easily the most alluring aspect of the game. There is a persistently mystifying ambiance which is juxtaposed with suggestions of an unknown actual reality.  It feels like you’re down the rabbit hole. There are clear and strong influences from games like Portal, Limbo, and The Stanley Parable.

It won’t appeal to everyone. It is/was clearly a very small project that is intentionally compact and quaint. But if you are like me and like these types of riddles, then you probably will enjoy this entertaining, but quite brief, game. Consider it for a price you are comfortable with and give it a whirl.

Short logic puzzle game. (The tags lie.)

The challenge in this game is to pass through 23 doors that lead to bacon - and to not pass through the approximately 100 doors that lead to death (which means retry, because there's autosave if you haven't turned it off). In every puzzle is a door that leads to bacon. All other doors lead to death.

reviewText:
There's not much here to not like.  The puzzles made me engage my noodle; the first achievement I got made me laugh out loud; the description is honest about it being short.  I loved Portal and Portal 2, and enjoyed Antichamber, so I took a risk.  I'm glad I did.

It's a little pricey for what amounts to a very brief book of logic puzzles, but it is attractive if not actually pretty, and has a bit of mystery to it.  If I have one complaint it's that we're supposed to buy that anyone could be expected to believe the game is anything but a simulation, when everything around them is that Limbo-esque, foggy black that Unity game designers use to look arty and so they don't have to design textures.

...That's for giving me that first achievement, Mr. Weibel.  You know the one I mean.

I'm also not wild about the sound design -- the sudden bangs are a little incontinence-inducing.  But that is a fine nit to pick.

If you like logic puzzles, and Doors is on sale, go on and pick it up.  I think $5 is a bit much to ask, but only because of its length.

Doors:
~~~~~

Well, there are no two ways about it – it’s either you reach the bacon (nice and crispy) by choosing the correct door, or you DIE!!

Doors is a walking simulator / puzzle games. You will be walking through this dark atmospheric world and the end of each short walk you will be presented with doors. A comment will be on the top of each door. Essentially it is a riddle; understand it and choose the right one and you will be closer to the bacon. At the start you will have a couple of doors, then a few, then several with different shapes which will make your neurones sparkle more than once. The riddles become progressively more challenging as you go alone.

I really enjoy the dark atmosphere in Doors - the slow, short walk to the door really makes you wonder what the next riddle is?

Well suited to those who enjoy riddle / puzzle games, although I encourage everybody to give it a go, even if you are not familiar with the genre.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Good dark atmosphere
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Short game

Doors is a nice walking simulator/ puzzle game where you have to figure out the riddles and get the bacon at the end!
7/10

This is a neat little game. And by little I mean both minimalistic and short.
The logic puzzles that make up the core of the game are based around deductive reasoning. They range from very easy (introductory) to somewhat frustrating difficulties, but they're never too difficult to get through. And if you get stuck on one there's always the trial and error options of walking through doors, losing and retrying until you find the right one.

The underlying story is thin and not very well presented, but I think the lack of background is intended.
Anyway, the game should be played for the logic puzzles, not if you want story.

This game is too easy.

I love puzzle games. Too much, some would say. After finishing The Witness, i was craving more.
I had a look through some interesting games and i come across Doors. I figured it looks interesting enough to give it a go.

The game is a glorified version of the Knights and Knaves logic puzzle. You are given a set of statements, some are true, some are false and you need to figure out what to do with that information. In concept, a good idea for a puzzle game, but i think the game could have presented the puzzles better.

Each of the doors in the game were pritty much side by side and had no variations. The majority of the game consisted of a kinda empty scene in black and white. the modeling was very good, and i think a bit of colour and maybe a higher draw distance and the game would have been very beautiful, as well as that, when the game says it's short, it's really short. I was able to complete it within 50 minutes, and i was kinda disapointed it ended so soon, it felt like i was barely getting into the game when it ended.

The puzzles themselves were a little too straightforward. If you didn't take notes then it would be easy to see how people would make mistakes but given the instructions it wasnt too hard (all besides the very last puzzle, which even though i was able to work out down to two of thirty doors, there was no way i could find to decisivly figure out which one was correct without guessing)

TL:DR

This game is a lot like a cheap burger.

Sure it's good but its not very filling, and also it's really bland and plain, it needs something to spice it up a little and i think it would be much better. 4/10

BugZy's Review: Doors - Bacon is wonderful

The following is my opinion.

Mmm, bacon.

Doors is a superb atmospheric logic puzzler with a simplistic art style developed and published by Calvin Weibel, fueled by bacon. You have to use the power of deduction and true or false facts given to choose which portal - or 'door' - to go through. One or more doors leads to bacon, the others death and sometimes, a door leads to an office.

If you have played before and know most of the correct doors it'll be a breeze, but it makes up for that by making your first time very difficult, especially if - like me - you weren't expecting something quite so challenging. Get your brain working, because you'll need it!

It plays very smoothly, a few frame rate hiccups every so often but nothing so bad as to be game-breaking. There is also no HUD but in all honesty, Doors has no reason to have it.

Despite being simplistic, the game is visually brilliant with the audial ambience just as great. One moment you're staring into the void of black and grey, trying to figure out which door takes you one step closer to your delicious victory and never-ending supply of bacon, the next, you're wandering through an office as though you own the place. The sound effects add to the mysterious atmosphere as well, sounding somewhat like you have entered the stomach of a dinosaur.

Overall, the game is a great concept brought to the world using an almost perfect balance of atmosphere and gameplay for a puzzler like this and if you enjoy games of the puzzle genre, I highly recommend you buy it.

I give it 9 out of 10 juicy rashers of bacon.

reviewText:
I recieved a free, early copy from the developer. Keep that in mind.

If you’d prefer a video review, have a look here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o9VQ9P9A4mY

The whole gameplay loop is that you’re presented with doors and some instructions, and all but one leads to death, and the one that doesn’t, apparently, leads to bacon.

I was a little torn with the presentation. On one hand it’s simple and clean, on the other I think you could argue it’s a bit boring. I tend to lean to the former rather than the latter, but I do think there’s a small subset of people who would be put off by it; if you’re not a fan of the bleakness of a game like Limbo, say, in terms of colour and style, then you’re not going to be stopping to take in the world. All that said, I think it serves the purpose well; I much prefer a simpler approach like this as opposed to an ugly attempt at something more complicated. It also fits in quite well with the story, and there is a story, and a theme, and an atmosphere, but i’ll talk about that in a sec.

The mechanics, well, there aren’t really any gameplay mechanics. This is where the game is going to lose most people. It’s not a walking simulator, like dear Esther, but it’s hard for me to class it completely as [PAUSE] a puzzle game. I’d say approach it more as a short brainteaser book that, doesn’t have too many puzzles and they're all really the same puzzle at varying difficulties but, there’s also a narrative there that you need to read between the lines to discover as you continue on in the book. I’m not saying it’s not a game, it is a game, but it has that quality where it’s for a very specific kind of person. Not necessarily for the person that loved Gone Home, but maybe a fan of The Witness would enjoy it, or any other puzzle game that asks a lot of the player. And the mechanics have their own intrinsic issues; you can brute force the game by guessing the answers and, I’ll admit, I ended up guessing a lot of the final puzzle in impulsive frustration. The fact that it’s possible to do so I think should be put down as a negative mark for the game, because I’d argue that, unless you have the will of a black hole, the minute most people get frustrated they’ll begin to just guess in order to beat the puzzle.I do think that’s a design flaw, but at the same time it’s slightly difficult to criticise a game for giving you more options you know?

So there is a story to the game. In particular before I say anything specific I'd like to talk about the atmosphere, and I think it’s pretty much as good you can get for a game like this. It’s a really interesting mix of horror and humour, and I think it works. Ambient, ominous noises chirp away at your ears, if you’re wearing headphones, but at the same time your final goal always seems to be.. bacon, which is so tongue and cheek -- I think there’s people who would argue that’s almost a little too much in the other direction. In terms of the actual story itself, and underlying narrative, I thought it was super interesting. If you want to know nothing going in, which I’d recommend, I’d say you should hit that annotation on the top right that will take you directly to the score, or hit the temporary one in the top left to take you to the overall verdict section. The fact is, the story is so minimal, that to say anything about it might be a major spoiler for some people. I’ll still try and keep it as vague as possible. I do wish there was a little more to the story than there was, but it was good enough to give an otherwise empty, soulless, game, a breath of life. It gives it some heart and context; I could imagine what the scenario was, and it managed to make the mix of the two H’s: Horror and Humour, actually make sense. There’s a reason why some things are scary, and there’s a reason why some things are ridiculous. It all makes sense within the context of the story and, I’ll harp on about it, story is a huge part of a lot of games because it’s the glue that brings all of the pieces together to work as a cohesive whole, and even if the mechanics didn’t satisfy me much, I still felt like I had a complete experience because of the story.

In the end I got a couple hours out of the game, and it was a fairly interesting experience. Personally I’d say that the $5 is not necessarily too expensive, but I do think it could be lower. There is a discount for the game on launch which I believe will bring the price down another dollar, but, ultimately, I’ve gotten way more out of some games that even cheaper. Blitz Breaker is a recent game I reviewed; I got 15 hours out of the game and it’s $3 on Steam. I also think that was a much prettier game with a lot more visual polish; what i’m saying, is that the pricing of Doors could be a lot better, or the game could have more to offer. I’d say, if you like games such as The Witness in terms of the style of gameplay, and you like minimal suggestive storytelling, and you don’t mind if there isn’t much eye candy; maybe you want an experience kinda like The Witness but in a bite-size portion -- I think in that case it’s probably a must buy. I just don’t know how many people that actually is; it’s really a unique game directed at a unique audience.

SCORE:

PRESENTATION: 7
MECHANICS: 6
STORY: 8
PRICE/QUALITY: 6
PERSONAL ENJOYMENT: 4

FINAL: 6.2/10

Doors get an above average, 6.2 out of 10. It’s a full point above average. The presentation was ok but a little boring; what pushed it up to 7 rather than 5 or 6, was the quite striking contrast between the doors and the rest of the environment, which I liked, and the thematic relevance of the presentation as a whole, including spoilerific parts of the game.

I do think the mechanics are above average, they show a level of creativity beyond what tends to turn up in the Steam store, but I also have a hard time imagining someone loving the game, or even really enjoying it. And I think that comes down to the fact that there really isn’t a mechanical reason for this to be a game, if that makes sense. It’s just logic puzzles that anyone could look up online, but the thing that makes this different from an online blog, is of course the story which I rate quite highly. It’s handled pretty well, and gets the point across, I just wish there was a little bit more of it, and a bit more fleshed out. admittedly I didn’t look into the details of the story, but I’m just talking about a few more story beats for the casual player. The story also didn’t blow me away, it’s not the next Portal 2 in terms of originality.

The price is good. It’s pretty fitting. $5 for two or three hours is, like, really really acceptable. I’d maybe even lean towards cheap, which is why it gets a 6. But it could have been more for the price, or cheaper still.

If we’re talking personally though? I just found myself frustrated at the puzzles a lot. I didn’t really feel good solving them either. My brain isn’t really built for logic puzzles. I would have rated it lower for enjoyment if the story hadn’t intrigued me as much as it did, though. It’s one of those things where I can recognise a pretty good game, but I didn’t really like it myself.

Let's start with the good.
The ambiance is lovely, and the graphics are minimalist, yet charming.  There is a semblance of a vague storyline.  The puzzles get challenging towards the end. There is an obvious lack of any sort of finished story.  I would rather like a sequel to come along and sort out everything.  It just...stops.  End of story.  Some parts of the office were very intrigung, and an explanation would have been wonderful.  There were only a few puzzles.  It's a short game.  An extremely short game.  I was almost disappointed by its shortness.
But I'm recommending this game anyways, with the caution that it is short and sweet.
6/10 Fun while it lasted.

While it is clear (sometimes to an eye-rolling level) that the creator was trying very hard to capture the Stanley Parable/Portal humor style, they were not entirely successful. However, that's not why I bought the game.

The environments were interesting, and the puzzles grew more and more rewarding (you start celebrating when you figure one out on your first go). The final puzzle was my favorite.

One word of advice: use diagrams if you have trouble with this stuff, especially as the doors start becoming more and more numerous.

In addition, before each set of doors there is some text on the ground that gives further information you need to solve the puzzle (usually telling you how many of the doors are lying to you). reviewText:
TL;DR: interesting game, poor execution. Not worth the $4.99 price tag, give it a go if it's 80% off.

I really wanted to like this game. The atmosphere looked intruiging, the idea seemed novel, but all I got was a repetitive mess with puzzles that are better solved with trial and error than actual thought. Some of the puzzles are clever riddles, but most are not in any way logical and just require trying each door until you find the right one, which can be a pain when the walk back after a death is long (neat trick: save just before you try a door, and when you die, click to go to the menu instead and just reload your save, it's much quicker).

The black and gray levels (save for one) become very boring to look at, and after a while I found myself just trudging through the last few puzzles to what was hopefully a rewarding end (it wasn't).

I suppose my biggest beef with the game is its price tag. There's just not enough here to warrant it. If you come across the title at a steep discount, give it a try, otherwise steer clear.

reviewText:
I'd give this game 6.5 / 10 and that's because of the lack of substance in the game... the atmosphere and all else are good.

The only reason I can recommend this game is because it costs less than $5. I'd further recommend that you wait for sale before you pick it up.

https://youtu.be/calbbb79tU4

Like all of the other reviews I have the same complaint. The game is too short and in more ways than one. There are around 20 doors or puzzles, and each puzzle is maybe only a minute or so long. So it felt like I was burning through the game really fast.

I would suggest that the developers work on more interactivity on each level. Instead of a path approaching doors, add a bit more to distract the player... possibly even more puzzles to solve in order to reach the doors. That would add a lot more to beef the game up and give it some more substance.

It certainly has the feel of Limbo and The Stanley Parable, but that's just it... It's as if they took those two design elements and mixed them rather non-homogeniously (they don't mesh.)

The experience is worth it for a low price, and other than that... if you like logic puzzles... you're good to go. I wouldn't consider these puzzles to be very difficult, not that I got them all on the first shot either though.

The puzzles kind of remind me of the brain teasers we used to get in grade school. Fun times!

This is a game that you can quick force or take your time to enjoy.  You do play much of it on paper, but that's no bad thing.  Right now I'm playing a level at a time.  Some of the puzzles are making my brain bleed, but they are DAMN well constructed.  My only critical point is that on choosing the wrong door, you should not simply be taken back to the start of the level.  Maybe if there was some reward for getting the puzzle correct first time.

I can see that the game maker has relied on so many influences, from portal to parable.  I think he has done himself a disservice here, as the game could stand on it's own two feet for it's well crafted puzzles.  Having said that, it's the trailer really drew me to this game.  In hindsight I may not have picked it up without those references.

If you like a challenge then give this a go.  I'm surprised that the reviews have been so mixed.  I'm just as happy in this world solving puzzles as I am in “The Witness”.

Pros:

date:
what it means is it completely rips off the visual style of those games.

Despite all the cons I'd still generally recommend it.  I mostly enjoyed it for the brief time it lasted.  I've wasted $4 on worse things before so I'm not going to lose sleep over it, but it feels like it should be a free demo version of a much longer and more varied game.
